data.text: Is any part of the property listed?

data.info: Listed building consent is required for physical changes to a listed property. It is a criminal offence to proceed with works that would damage or harm the historic character of a listed building without planning consent from the local planning authority.
data.text: Do the proposals include physical changes to the property?
data.policyRef: Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990
data.description: This includes construction, alterations or changes that would affect the setting of a listed building
data.howMeasured:
This applies not just to the main building, but also any original outbuildings, walls, gates, fences that were built before 1948, or around the time the property was first constructed if built after 1948.

This also applies to any internal works that would affect any historic fabric, features or character of the property.

data.title: We would love to hear your feedback.
data.description:
You can now close this window, or start a new application.

If you have found this service useful, or would like to suggest a way we can improve it, please let us know using the feedback link at the bottom of the page.

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is in a conservation area with a trunk larger than 100mm, you must provide notice to your local planning authority before proceeding with any of the following actions:

  • cutting down
  • cutting roots
  • topping
  • lopping
  • uprooting
  • wilful damage (including to roots)
  • wilful destruction

It is an offence to carry out any of these actions without providing notice to your local planning authority. Your local planning authority then has a period of 6 weeks (from the date of the notice) to respond and/or to place a protection order on that tree if required. If they do not respond within 6 weeks, you then have a legal right to proceed with the works, provided they are completed within a period of 2 years from the same date.
data.text: Might the works affect any tree with a trunk wider than 100mm?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Tree Preservation)(England) Regulations 2012 Part 3
data.description: For example, by damaging its branches or its roots
data.howMeasured: Trunk diameter is measured around the bark of the trunk at a height of 1.5m above the natural ground level. If the tree has more than one stem at this height, you should measure the diameter of the largest stem at that level.

data.text: What types of changes does the project involve?
Internal works, changes of use or changes of unit only

TR-REQUIRED.heading: You also need to apply for Works to Trees consent
TR-REQUIRED.description: It looks like you will also need to submit a Works to Trees application. This is a separate form of planning consent to planning permission. You can find out more about how to do this on our website.

TR-DE_MINIMIS.heading: You need to notify us about works to trees
TR-DE_MINIMIS.description: It looks like you wil need to provide notice of works to trees. This is a separate requirement.

TR-MISSING_INFO.heading: You might also need to apply for Works to Trees consent
TR-MISSING_INFO.description: It looks like you may also need to submit a Works to Trees application. This is a separate form of planning consent to planning permission.

TR-NOT_REQUIRED.heading: Works to Trees consent not required

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is protected by a Tree Preservation Order (TPO), the following works need consent from your local planning authority:

  • cutting down
  • cutting roots
  • topping
  • lopping
  • uprooting
  • wilful damage (including to roots)
  • wilful destruction

It is an offence to carry out any of these actions without consent from your local planning authority.

data.title: Describe your connection
data.description: Provide details of your role within the council

data.text: I am an elected member for Southwark Council

data.info: Any Certificate of Lawfulness or planning consent issued on the basis of inaccurate or knowingly incomplete information may be legally invalid.

data.text: I am an employee of Southwark Council

data.info: It is an important principle of the planning system that decision-making processes are open and transparent. Declaring a connection will not affect the way your application is assessed. It will simply ensure that it is processed in a way that is fair and impartial.
data.description: This applies to either applicant or agents
data.howMeasured:
Partnered includes unmarried couples, as married couples or couples in a civil partnership.

Related to can include any relation (whether by birth, marriage or adoption) who is close enough that a fair-minded and informed observer, having considered the facts, might conclude that there was a risk of bias on the part of the decision maker within the planning authority.

If you are unsure, it is better to declare any connection so steps can be taken to avoid any situation where an accusation of bias could be made.

Do agents need to declare a connection?

Yes. You should declare any council connections with either the applicant or an agent completing an application on the applicant's behalf.

data.info: Listed building consent is required for physical changes to a listed property. It is a criminal offence to proceed with works that would damage or harm the historic character of a listed building without planning consent from the local planning authority.
data.title: You may also need to apply for Listed Building Consent
data.policyRef: Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990
data.description:
Please note that because the property is listed you may also need to apply for Listed Building Consent. This is a separate form of consent to planning permission. Applications for Listed Building Consent can be submitted separately, but do not carry any additional planning fee.

It is a criminal offence to alter or damage a listed building without consent.
data.howMeasured:
Definition: Listed Building

"...means a building which is for the time being included in a list compiled or approved by the Secretary of State under this section; and for the purposes of this Act -

(a) any object or structure fixed to the building;

(b) any object or structure within the curtilage of the building which, although not fixed to the building, forms part of the land and has done so since before 1st July 1948,

shall subject to subsection (5A)(a) be treated as part of the building."

s1(5) Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990

Definition: Listed Building Consent (LBC)

Consent from the local planning authority (or in some circumstances the Secretary of State) for the demolition of a listed building or the carrying out of any works for the alteration or extension of a listed building in any manner that would affect its character as a building of special architectural or historic interest. Failure to obtain consent when it is needed is a criminal offence.

s8 Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990

data.description: If your application for a Certificate of Lawfulness is refused, the planning fee for this application will not be refundable.

data.info:
There are 2 types Lawful Development Certificate (LDC) you can apply for.

Proposed changes

This type of LDC is for changes you want to make in the future including:

  • physical changes to the property
  • changes in how the property is used

A certificate will confirm that the proposed changes are lawful before you start work.

We will assess this type of application under Section 192 of the legislation.

Existing changes

This type of LDC is:

  • for changes that were made in the past
  • to confirm whether the current use of the property is lawful

These are sometimes called retrospective applications.

We will assess this type of application under Section 191 of the legislation.

data.info:
In most cases, development becomes immune from enforcement if no action is taken:

- within 4 years of substantial completion for a breach of planning control consisting of operational development;
- within 4 years for an unauthorised change of use to a single dwellinghouse;
- within 10 years for any other breach of planning control (essentially other changes of use).

These time limits are set out in [section 171B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1990/8/section/171B).

However, the time-limits set out above do not prevent enforcement action after the relevant dates in certain circumstances. These are:

- [section 171B(4)(b) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1990/8/section/171B), which provides for the taking of further enforcement action in respect of any breach of planning control within 4 years of previous enforcement action (or purported action) in respect of the same breach. This mainly deals with the situation where earlier enforcement action has been taken, within the relevant time-limit, but has later proved to be defective, so that a further notice may be issued or served, as the case may be, even though the normal time-limit for such action has since expired. This is known as the second bite provision
- where there has been deliberate concealment of a breach of planning control, local planning authorities may apply for a [planning enforcement order](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/ensuring-effective-enforcement#Planning-Enforcement-Order) to allow them to take action after the time limits in section 171B have expired
- where a person has deliberately concealed a breach of planning control, the courts have found that in these circumstances, the time limits in section 171B do not engage until the breach has been discovered (see Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government and another v Welwyn Hatfield Borough Council and Bonsall / Jackson v Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government).

Therefore, in cases of deliberate concealment, a local planning authority may decide to serve an enforcement notice out of time or apply for a planning enforcement order. It is for the local planning authority to decide which approach is appropriate in each case.

In cases where physical work has been carried out, completion means 'substantial completion' rather than total completion.

In the cases where only the use of the property has changed, 'completed' means the date on which the property began to be used in its new use.

You may find this information in communications or invoices from your architects, builders or building control inspector. If you are unsure of a precise completion date, you should add the earliest date for which you have evidence.

data.heading: Application sent
data.moreInfo:
You will be contacted

  • if there is anything missing from the information you have provided so far
  • if any additional information is required
  • to arrange a site visit, if required
  • to inform you whether a certificate has been granted or not

How useful was this service?

This is a new service, and we are looking for ways to improve it. Please let us know how you found it, and your ideas for how we can make it better.

Tell us how you found this service (5 mins)(opens in new tab)

nextSteps.title: Validation
nextSteps.description: Your application will be checked for any errors and missing information. This will usually be done within 15 working days. If there are any issues or we need more information, we will contact you.

nextSteps.title: Site visit
nextSteps.description: In some cases it may be necessary for a planning officer to visit the property. If this is the case, we may contact you to arrange a date and time for the visit.

nextSteps.title: Assessment
nextSteps.description: A planning officer will assess your application against the relevant planning policies and legislation. If we find we need any further information from you at this stage, we will contact you.

nextSteps.title: Decision
nextSteps.description: If there are no errors or missing information, you can usually expect to receive a decision within 8 weeks. If we need more time we will contact you to agree this. We will email you a Lawful Development Certificate, or explain why a certificate cannot be granted.

data.contactInfo:
Contact us if:

  • You do not receive an email confirming that we have received your application within 24 hours or the next working day.
  • You have any questions about your application or this service.

Telephone 020 7525 5403

Monday to Friday, 9am–5.30pm (except public holidays)

Email planningpolicy@southwark.gov.uk

We aim to respond within 2 working days.

data.description: You can subtract any floor area that is being demolished.
data.howMeasured: This question refers to gross internal area. This means measuring to the internal face of the perimeter walls at each floor level. It includes all internal walls and all voids over stairs. However it does not include voids to the floor below (for example, a double height space). Find our more about how to measure Gross Internal Area.

data.policyRef: The Community Infrastructure Levy Regulations 2010, Regulation 4

data.title: It looks like a Community Infrastructure Levy (CIL) will be payable on this development
data.policyRef: The Community Infrastructure Levy Regulations 2010
data.description: Development that adds a new internal floor area of 100m² or more, or creates additional new homes must pay a Community Infrastrucutre Levy (CIL) upon completion of the works. You will need to provide us with some additional information to help us calculate the correct levy amount.

data.info: The application may be exempt from Community Infrastruture Levy (CIL), but only if the property is the appliant's primary residence.
data.text: Does the applicant live at the property?
data.policyRef: The Community Infrastructure Levy (Amendment) Regulations 2014, Regulation 7
data.description: Answer yes if the property is their primary residence
data.howMeasured: Primary residence means the place where you live most of the time. It is also likely to be the main address you use.

data.info:
In the case of self-build homes you can apply for an exemption from Community Infrastructure Levy. You will need to:

  • Make a declaration that your scheme meets the criteria. This can be done as part of this application.
  • Notify us of the commencement date before works begin.
  • Following completion you will need to submit further information and evidence to us within 6 months of completing the self-build home.

You can read further guidance on the GOV.UK guidance pages.
data.text: Is the applicant building a home for themselves?
data.policyRef: The Community Infrastructure Levy (Amendment) Regulations 2014, Regulation 7
data.description: Answer yes if the house will be the applicant's primary residence, and they do not intend to sell or let the house within 3 years.
data.howMeasured: If the property, or part of the property is sold or let within 3 years of completion, the exemption will be void and CIL will be payable.

data.info: There is no prescribed way to prove that the changes were completed on or before the date you have stated. However, for a Certificate of Lawfulness to be issued, you must provide sufficient evidence for the planning officer to have confidence that the changes were completed on that date.
data.description: Select the documents you want to submit
data.howMeasured:
What does 'completion' mean?

In the case of physical works, completion means 'substantial completion'. In the case of a change of use, the date would the date upon which the property came into the new use.

Photographs do not in themselves constitute evidence. However they can be submitted in conjunction with another form of evidence.

data.info:
This type of project always requires planning permission if the changes have already been carried out in the past. These changes can include changes in how the property is used, or physical works.

If you were applying about proposed future changes, you would have an option to apply for Prior Approval before commencing with the changes, instead of plannign permission. However, since the changes have already happened, you will need to apply for retrospective planning permission.
data.text: Have the changes already been made?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015
data.description: Answer yes if you are applying about works that have already been done in the past.
Leave this application.

data.title: Application Reference Number
data.description: You can find this on the decision letter from your application for Prior Approval
This is a separate type of planning consent. We will give you information about how to apply.

data.info: This description will be used on the public decision notice. Your planning officer will check this description, to make sure it accurately reflects the changes, and may ask you to amend it before the application can be assessed.
data.title: Describe the project
data.description: Write a brief description of the changes using two sentences or fewer. For example, 'Proposed single storey rear extension and insertion of 2 skylights to side elevations'.
data.howMeasured:
You do not need to describe the reason for the works, only the main headline changes that will be taking place. This description should not include any personal information.

Do not include personal information such as names, addresses, emails or phone numbers.

Some examples

Hip to gable roof extension with dormer windows to front and rear

Single storey extension to side to form residential annexe

Demolition of existing dwelling and construction of one dwelling

Erection of a 1.5 metre high fence along the rear boundary

You may add additional detail where it is useful. For example, if you are replacing windows you may choose to specify further information about the materials and colour of the the windows in relation to the existing building.

data.title: Upload existing floor plans
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015 (as amended)
data.description: For each level of the building affected by the changes, upload a plan of the property as it looks before the work.
data.howMeasured:
Your floor plans must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:100 or 1:50 at A3 or A4 size paper
  • Have a scale bar
  • Show the direction of North
  • Have a unique drawing reference number
  • Be clearly titled and labelled

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately show the site and the proposed changes.

data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015 (as amended)

data.howMeasured:

  • Have a scale bar
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the proposed changes.

data.text: Yes, alterations to the shape of a roof

data.title: Upload proposed site plan
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015 (as amended)
data.description: Upload a plan showing the position of all buildings on the property as they will look after the work.
data.howMeasured:
Your site plan must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:500 or 1:200 at A3 or A4 size paper
  • Have a scale bar
  • Show the direction of North
  • Have a unique drawing reference number
  • Be based on an up-to-date map or survey

It should include

  • Buildings including outbuildings
  • Trees on or adjoining the site
  • Roads
  • Public footpaths or rights of way
  • Hard surfaces such as patios or decks
  • Boundaries such as walls or fences

If you are showing the red site outline on your drawing, please make sure it matches the red line boundary you drew earlier.

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately show the site and the proposed changes.

data.info:
Any photos you upload may be published online as part of our planning register. Try to avoid uploading photographs that show:

  • People
  • Indoor areas
  • Valuable items, vehicles or machinery

In most cases, your planning officer will remove photographs that contain any of these, or anything else that they think might be sensitive or highly private. Check our privacy policy for more details.

PP-NOTICE.heading: You need to notify us
PP-NOTICE.description: It looks like part of the changes described in this application require you to provide written notice to us. You can proceed with this application, but that this application may not itself constitute written notice. You should send this separately if you have not already done so. Check the details below.

PRIOR_APPROVAL.heading: It looks like these changes will require Prior Approval
PRIOR_APPROVAL.description: It looks like this project may require Prior Approval before a Lawful Development Certificate can be issued.This means that you must seek approval from the local planning authority that specific elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed.   If you have already applied for Prior Approval, you will be able to continue with this application.   If you have not yet applied for Prior Approval, we will provide you with information about how to apply.

PLANNING_PERMISSION_REQUIRED.heading: It looks like these changes will require planning permission
PLANNING_PERMISSION_REQUIRED.description: If this is the case your application for a Lawful Development Certificate could be refused. This result is only based on the answers you have given. It is not an official planning decision.

data.info:
You'll need planning permission unless the last use of the space before it became a flat was for a commercial use (Class E), a betting shop or pay day loans shop.

Taxi offices and vehicle hire offices fall under their own 'Sui Generis' use class, and always need planning permission to change use.
data.text: What will the flat be converted into?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015, Schedule 2, Part 3, Class H
data.howMeasured: The Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) (Amendment) (England) Regulations 2020 (SI 757)

data.info:
You will need planning permission if the building is on land that is any of the following:

  • article 2(3) land
  • site of special scientific interest
  • listed building or land within its curtilage
  • scheduled monument or land within its curtilage
  • safety hazard area
  • military explosives storage area
  • land within 3km of the perimeter of an aerodrome
data.text: Is the property within 3km of the perimeter of an aerodrome?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 20, Class AC.
data.description: This applies to any part of the property

data.policyRef: [by Lichfields (1st September 2020)](https://lichfields.uk/media/6158/guide-to-the-use-classes-order-in-england.pdf),[ Planning Geek](https://www.planninggeek.co.uk/gpdo/)

data.info:
You will need planning permission to install or replace any plant on the new roof that is higher than any plant on the existing building.

Development of this type always needs prior approval.
data.text: Will the new plant equipment be higher than plant equipment on the existing building?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 20, Class AA.

data.text: Not on the main part of the building

data.info: You will need planning permission for new forestry buildings if any part of the development is within 25 metres of the metalled portion of a trunk road or classified road.

data.text: Have any other buildings on the holding already been converted to homes?
data.description: This include buildings on other sites operated by the same farmer or farming business.
data.howMeasured:
'Holding' here is defined as the 'agricultural unit'.

_“agricultural unit_” means agricultural land which is occupied as a unit for the purposes of agriculture, including— (a) any dwelling or other building on that land occupied for the purpose of farming the land by the person who occupies the unit, or ( b ) any dwelling on that land occupied by a farmworker;

So the agricultural unit can include both farm buildings, farmland and farmhouses operated as a farming business. This is not limited to a single site or a single property title. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are physically connected they will be considered as being part of one 'agricultural unit'. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are not physically connected, it is very probably that the will also be considered to consitute a single agricultural unit, depending on their proximity. If in doubt you should contact your local planning authority before proceeding with any works.

It may be a criminal offence if you fail to notify your local plannign authority correctly.

A semi-detached building is a building that shares a wall with (or adjoins) one other building in a row of 2 houses.

A terraced building is a building that shares a wall with (or adjoins) at least one other building in a row of 3 or more houses.

A detached building is a building that does not adjoin any other buildings.

data.text: Will there be any risk of groundwater contamination?
data.howMeasured: This refers to activities that may take place on or near the new hard surface. Activities such as light industry, heavy industry or anything involving sewage, or hazardous, harmful or inorganic chemicals, for example, are likely to pose a risk of groundwater contamination. Activities such as parking cars are unlikely to pose a significant risk, unless it is regularly used as a place to carry out repair works on vehicles.

data.info:
Structures that extend 3m or less from the respective rear wall of a semi-detached house may not need planning permission.

Structures that extend between 3 and 6m from the rear wall may not require planning permission but will need prior approval.

Otherwise, you will need planning permission.
data.text: How far does the new addition extend beyond the back wall of the original house?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A.1 (f)(i)
data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

Structures that extend 3m or less from the respective rear wall of a terraced house may not need planning permission. 

Structures that extend between 3 and 6m from the rear wall may not need planning permission but will need prior approval. 

Otherwise, you will need planning permission.
data.text: How far does the new addition extend beyond the back wall of the original house?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A.1 (f)(i)
data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is in a conservation area with a trunk larger than 100mm, you must provide notice to your local planning authority before proceeding with any of the following actions:

  • cutting down
  • cutting roots
  • topping
  • lopping
  • uprooting
  • wilful damage (including to roots)
  • wilful destruction

In the case of a tree that is in a conservation area with a trunk larger than 75mm but less than 100mm, the same is true, except that there are some exceptions.

It is an offence to carry out any of these actions without providing notice to your local planning authority. Your local planning authority then has a period of 6 weeks (from the date of the notice) to respond and/or to place a protection order on that tree if required. If they do not respond within 6 weeks, you then have a legal right to proceed with the works, provided they are completed within a period of 2 years from the same date.
data.text: What is the diameter of the tree trunk?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Tree Preservation)(England) Regulations 2012 Part 3
data.howMeasured: Trunk diameter is measured around the bark of the trunk at a height of 1.5m above the natural ground level. If the tree has more than one stem at this height, you should measure the diameter of the largest stem at that level.

data.info:
A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) that is occupied by six people or fewer falls into use class C4. This use class benefits from General Permitted Development Rights that permit certain kinds of development to be carried out without planning permission.

An HMO occupied by 7 or more people falls into its own 'Sui Generis' use class and therefore planning permission will be required.

data.policyRef: Palm Developments Ltd v Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government, 2009
data.description: Select all that apply.
data.howMeasured: In 2009, Mr Justice Cranston concluded that: "There is no statutory definition of a tree. I conclude that with tree preservation orders there are no limitations in terms of size for what is to be treated as a tree. In other words, saplings are trees. 'Tree' must therefore mean anything that would ordinarily be regarded as a tree. Thus it would not include a shrub, a bush or scrub."

data.info:
Within Greater London, the use of homes as temporary sleeping accommodation requires planning permission. This applies even if only part of the premises is used as temporary sleeping accommodation.

However planning permission is not required if two tests are met:

(a) it is used for temporary sleeping accommodation for 90 or fewer nights in a calendar year.

(b) the person who provided the sleeping accommodation was liable to pay council tax (which would therefore include people who are liable to council tax but are in receipt of a discount) during the time when the property was used as temporary sleeping accommodation.

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is in a conservation area with a trunk between 75mm-100mm in diameter, you must provide notice to your local planning authority before proceeding with any of the following actions:

  • cutting down
  • uprooting
  • wilful destruction

Unless the sole reason for the action is to improve the growth of other trees.

It may be a criminal offence to carry out any of these actions without providing notice to your local planning authority.

Your local planning authority then has a period of 6 weeks (from the date of the notice) to respond and/or to place a protection order on that tree if required. If they do not respond within 6 weeks, you then have a legal right to proceed with the works, provided they are completed within a period of 2 years from the same date.

Dead trees

In the case of a tree that is dead the developer must provide at least 5 days' notice to the local planning authority before works begin.

Fruit trees

In the case of a fruit tree that is used in then course of a business or trade, then notice is not required, provided the work being done is solely in the interest of that business or trade, and no other reason.

Dangerous trees

In the case of works to a tree that are urgently needed to avoid the risk of serious harm, and it is not possible to notify your local planning authority before carrying out the works, you must notify them as soon as possible after carrying out the work.

If the works to make a tree safe are less urgent, you must notify your local planning authority at least 5 working days before commencing the works.

It may be a criminal offence if you fail to notify your local plannign authority correctly.
data.text: Why is the tree being cut down?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Tree Preservation)(England) Regulations 2012 Part 3
data.description: Select all reasons that apply

The local authority team will make an assessment based on:

data.info: Change of use of part a house to an annexe that will be occupied by a member of the household or family (such as an older relative) is unlikely to need planning permission.
data.notes:
Generally 'granny annexes' do not need planning permission, allowing an annexe connected to a house to be kitted out with facilities necessary for independent living (such as bathrooms, kitchens, bedrooms), as long as the annexe remains under the aegis of the main house.
From a legal standpoint, the ability to undertake this conversion hinges on whether a material change of use would occur under Section 55 (1) rather than whether the proposal met any permitted development rights under the provisions of the GPDO.
Providing an additional bedroom, a living area, kitchen and bathroom cannot be construed as "incidental" as per S55 (2d) as it resulted in primary accommodation, but it does not necessarily follow that a material change of use would occur in these circumstances. The real question is whether a separate dwellinghouse and a new planning unit would be formed. The judgment in Uttlesford DC v SOS and White, 1991 holds that there was no reason in law why a granny annexe with all the facilities for day-to-day living would automatically become a separate planning unit.
There are circumstances where the proposal for conversion is motivated by an older generation wishing to downsize, rather than to meet any current healthcare needs. The old generation may be more than likely to live independently of those in the 'main house', which would go against the general view of what a granny annexe normally constituted. However, if a 'separate planning unit' would not be formed, there is a sufficently intimate physical relationship between the dwelling and the annex, a lack of any physical subdivision of the garden, driveway or parking areas, no separate address would be created such that utilities would be billed as a single property, in some judges view this meets the base criteria of being a granny annexe. Use as a granny annexe does not certify that the use of the property would be lawful if used in a different manner from that put forward or if circumstances were to change in future.
data.policyRef: Town and Country Planning Act 1990, Part 3, Section 55
data.howMeasured: 'Household' has the meaning set out in the Housing Act 2004. This includes those who are related to each other, married, in a civil partnership, or living together as if married.

data.info:
The Town and Country Planning Act 1990 55 (2) (f) stipulates that changing the use of a building to another use within the same use class does not count as development. The Town and Country Planning Act 1990 55 (3) (a) later goes on to make an exception when it comes to dwellinghouses: "For the avoidance of doubt it is hereby declared that for the purposes of this section the use as two or more separate dwellinghouses of any building previously used as a single dwellinghouse involves a material change in the use of the building and of each part of it which is so used".

It thus follows, in some people's view, that changing the use of PART of a non-dwellinghouse property (i.e. subdividing it), as long as that use falls within the same use category does not constitute development. Subsequently, this subdivided unit can have its use change again via any change of use permitted development.

For others, however, 55 (2) (f) may not necessarily apply to subdivision of a planning unit as such, although it certainly covers any change of use within the same use class. So for example, change of use from a butchers shop to use as a post office (both within Use Class A1) is not to be taken for the purposes of the Act to involve development of the land. But subdivision or amalgamation of planning units may nonetheless amount to a material change of use if it has the effect of changing the character of the use. The Court of Appeals judgment in Wakelin is one example, and the more recent High Court judgment in Richmond upon Thames LBC v SSETR [2001] J.P.L. 84 (involving the amalgamation of seven dwellings so as to re-convert the building to use as a single dwelling) is another example, where the change in the size of the planning unit was held to affect the character of the use in planning terms (in a broad sense, not confined to its possible environmental effects) and was thus a material change of use amounting to development, notwithstanding the fact that the earlier and later uses were all within one and the same use class.

This may come as a surprise to many people, as there seems to be a general assumption that section 55(2)(f) covers subdivision of a planning unit, so long as the use of all of the new planning units created by this subdivision remains within one and the same use class. Richmond clearly established that this is not necessarily so with regard to the amalgamation of two or more planning units, but it seems that the same could equally apply to the sub-division of a planning unit. A material change of use does not necessarily occur upon the sub-division of a planning unit, but if this changes the character of the use (in planning terms) then this may amount to a material change of use, notwithstanding section 55(2)(f).

It is quite frankly a grey area. It will be a matter of fact and degree, dependent of the precise circumstances of each such change to the planning unit.

data.info:
Development is permitted only on the condition that before starting the works, the owner should apply to the local planning authority for prior approval.

The local authority team will make an assessment on the basis of:

  • the design and appearance of the scheme
  • provision of adequate natural daylight to habitable rooms
  • impacts on light, views, privacy, flooding, air traffic or defence

You will also need to provide your local planning authority with a report for the management of the construction of the development including:

  • hours of operation
  • how any adverse impact of noise, dust, vibration and traffic on adjoining owners or occupiers will be mitigated

data.howMeasured: Habitable rooms are rooms used for living purposes but which are not solely a kitchen, utility room, bathroom, cellar or toilet.

data.info:
Planning permission is needed if the total capacity of all solar PV equipment on the property would exceed 1 megawatt.

Solar PV installations with a capacity of 50kW or less are 'microgeneration' and is permitted development.

If the total capacity is less than 1MW, but more than 50kW, you will need to seek a written determination from your local planning authority as to whether prior approval is needed, on the basis of any potential impact on neighbouring properties and the local area, in particular for example, the potential for glare.

data.info:
You may need planning permission if your project involves:

  • changing the external appearance of a building
  • a material change in the use of the property

Adding or removing a home always needs planning permission.

Significant underground excavations are likely to need planning permission since these excavations are considered to be development operations in their own right.

All other works that do not affect how the property looks from the outside and do not represent a material change in the use of the property do not constitute development, and therefore do not need planning permission.

A semi-detached building is a building that shares a wall with (or adjoins) one other building in a row of 2 houses.

A terraced building is a building that shares a wall with (or adjoins) at least one other building in a row of 3 or more houses.

A detached building is a building that does not adjoin any other buildings.

Structures that extend 3m or less from the respective rear wall of a terraced house may not need planning permission.

Structures that extend between 3 and 6m from the rear wall may not require planning permission but will need prior approval.

Otherwise, you will need planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is in a conservation area with a trunk greater than 100mm in diameter, you must provide notice to your local planning authority before proceeding with any of the following actions:

  • cutting down
  • uprooting
  • wilful destruction

Unless the sole reason for the action is to improve the growth of other trees.

It may be a criminal offence to carry out any of these actions without providing notice to your local planning authority.

Your local planning authority then has a period of 6 weeks (from the date of the notice) to respond and/or to place a protection order on that tree if required. If they do not respond within 6 weeks, you then have a legal right to proceed with the works, provided they are completed within a period of 2 years from the same date.

Dead trees

In the case of a tree that is dead the developer must provide at least 5 days' notice to the local planning authority before works begin.

Dangerous trees

In the case of works to a tree that are urgently needed to avoid the risk of serious harm, and it is not possible to notify your local planning authority before carrying out the works, you must notify them as soon as possible after carrying out the work.

If the works to make a tree safe are less urgent, you must notify your local planning authority at least 5 working days before commencing the works.

It may be a criminal offence if you fail to notify your local plannign authority correctly.

The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
Replacing windows of a flat does not require planning permission if the materials and appearance of the new windows are exactly identical to the old ones (like-for-like replacement), because these works to not constitute 'development'.

However, planning permission is needed if the materials or apperance of the new windows would only be similar to the old ones, or different.

data.policyRef: Town and Country Planning Act 1990, Part III, Section 55.

data.howMeasured: There is no precise definition of what constitutes 'identical' and 'similar' appearance. If in doubt, we recommend you should apply for a Lawful Development Certificate to establish whether the windows you intend to use meet this definition.

data.info: You’ll need planning permission if the flat or flats would be used for any purpose other than as a dwelling for a single family, or by up to 6 residents living together as a single household (including a household where care is provided for the residents).
data.text: Will the residents live together as a single household?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Section 2, Part 3, Class G.
data.howMeasured:
Members of a 'family' or 'household' are those who are related, married or living together as if they were married. This would include children who are legally adopted.

Housemates who are not related, or lodgers living with landlords would be considered as comprising multiple households.

In some rare cases (for example religious communities) it may be possible that a number of unrelated people who are not in a partnering relationship may live together in such a way as might be regarded as a single household

data.info:
Using a caravan for forestry purposes (such as storage, shelter for workers or as an office) falls outside planning controls if it is not used for residential use.

According to the Caravan Sites Act 1968, the legal definition of a caravan includes mobile homes and self-built structures.

Under this definition, the caravan does not need to have wheels if all of the following apply:

  • less than 60 feet long, 20 feet wide and 10 feet high
  • can be delivered in 2 sections (or fewer) by lorry
  • can be moved in one piece along a road when assembled
data.text: Is the immovable building more than 3m high?
data.policyRef: Caravan Sites Act 1968 Chapter 52, Part III, Section 13.
data.howMeasured:
A caravan is defined as a structure designed or adapted for human habitation.

It is made of a maximum of 2 sections that can be joined together on a site.

A caravan can be moved by road from one place to another. For example, being towed or on a trailer.

However, if your structure cannot lawfully be moved on a road when built it does not mean it is not a caravan.

Caravans must be less than:

  • 20 metres (65.6 feet) long. This excludes any drawbars that connect the caravan to the vehicle that pulls it
  • 6.8 metres (22.3 feet) wide
  • 3.05 metres (10 feet) high. This is measured from the floor to ceiling inside the caravan

data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house at any given point. So this dimension includes any prior extension that may have been added to the house. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is 'stepped', the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

data.howMeasured:
Is it a holiday let?

It is likely to be a holiday let if the following condiitons are met:

1) that the total of

(a) the number of nights of use and

(b) the number of nights of any previous use of the same premises as temporary sleeping accommodation in the same calendar year, is no greater than 90 nights;

2) for each night counted under (a), the person who provided the sleeping accommodation must be liable to pay council tax (which would therefore include people who are liable to council tax but are in receipt of a discount).

If these conditions are not met, the use of the building as temporary sleeping accommodation of residential properties creates a material change of use and needs planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
The 'original house' is the house as it was when first built, regardless of when that was.

'Additions' include any enclosed structure in the grounds of the house, including garden sheds, greenhouses, other storage buildings, swimming pools or other pools or containers (such as tanks).

The 'curtilage' of a house is the enclosed space of ground and buildings immediately surrounding a dwelling-house, that is used as part of the enjoyment of that home. In many cases this is the entire area within the property boundary, but not always. In some cases, the total property may include areas of land that are not part of the curtilage of the house. This can sometimes be an area where interpretation is needed. If you are unsure, you should consult a professional and/or apply for Certificate of Lawfulness before proceeding with any works.

The curtilage means the building and the immediate area of land that it is part of (if it has one), such as a driveway, yard or garden. data.description: Include the new extension and all existing extensions, outbuildings and tanks added since the house was first built.
data.howMeasured:
The 'original house' is the house as it was when first built, regardless of when that was.

'Additions' include any enclosed structure in the grounds of the house, including garden sheds, greenhouses, other storage buildings, swimming pools or other pools or containers (such as tanks).

The 'curtilage' of a house is the enclosed space of ground and buildings immediately surrounding a dwelling-house, that is used as part of the enjoyment of that home. In many cases this is the entire area within the property boundary, but not always. In some cases, the total property may also include areas of land that are not part of the curtilage of the house. This can sometimes be an area where interpretation is needed. If you are unsure, you should consult a professional and/or apply for a Certificate of Lawfulness before proceeding with any works.

If you are not sure how to calculate this figure, your architect should be able to measure it from your drawings or 3D models.

data.howMeasured:
This is measured as if there were an imaginary line across the front of the principal elevation of the house, extending all the way to the property boundary. You should not include bay windows, protrusions or previous additions.

The 'front' in this case means the principal elevation. The principal elevation usually means that side of the house which fronts (directly or at an angle) the main highway serving the house (the main highway will be the one that sets the postcode for the house concerned). It will usually (but not always) contain the main architectural features such as main bay windows or a porch serving the main entrance to the house.

In some cases (for example a house on a corner, or a house that appears to face sideway) it may not be clear which is the principal elevation. If unsure, you should consult your local planning authority.

data.notes: A planning appeal determined last January concerned a replacement  for a house which was burnt down in 1939 (DCS Number 100-055-961). The site was in low density housing area in the Chilterns Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The remains of the original walls existed to a maximum height of 2.5m, although vegetation had grown up inside the structure. The inspector considered whether the site qualified as previously developed land (PDL) and reasoned that in line with PPS3 Appendix B it had blended back into the landscape over the course of time. He observed that from public vantage points the site had the appearance of an undeveloped, overgrown plot of land.  I contend that the existence of walls up to 2.5m cannot have blended into the landscape in the words of PPS3. Lack of visibility from outside the site was due to an overgrown laurel hedge. What is your view on the apparent view of this inspector that a hedge around a site can result in the land not longer qualifying as PDL

data.howMeasured:
A trunk road is a road that is part of the national Strategic Road Network (SRN). These are managed by the Highways Agency, rather than by your local authority.

A classified road is a road with a number (for example, A-roads, B-roads or minor connecting roads, as opposed to unclassified roads, which are local roads that are likely to carry local traffic only.

Find out more about road classifications

Search road classifcations near you on FindMyStreet.

data.info:
A dwelling occupied by more than 3 people who are not from the same household (for example, not a family) is a House in Multiple Occupation (HMO). 

HMOs with 3 to 6 occupants fall under use class C4. 

HMOs with 7 or more occupants are 'large HMOs' and fall under their own 'Sui Generis' use class. 

Conversion of a family home (C3) to a small HMO (C4) is permitted development, and therefore does not need planning permission.

 Conversion of a family home to a large HMO always needs planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
A semi-detached building is a building that shares a wall with (or adjoins) one other building in a row of 2 houses.

A terraced building is a building that shares a wall with (or adjoins) at least 1 other building in a row of 3 or more houses.

A detached building is a building that does not adjoin any other buildings.

data.info:
Adding an outbuilding to a commercial or business building (falling into Class E of the Use Classes Order) always requires planning permission.

Works that involve significant excavation or engineering works (such as underpinning) are likely to need planning permission.
data.text: What is being added to the property?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015, Schedule 2, Part 7, Class A, Eatherley vs London Borough of Camden
data.howMeasured: Basement extensions are not explicitly covered by the legislation determining what is permitted development. For some time many planning authorities treated them as extensions covered by The General Permitted Development Order 2015. However, in 2016 the case of Eatherley vs London Borough of Camden set a precedent that significant excavations and engineering works (such as temporary propping and underpinning) constitute a separate activity of substance in their own right.

If you're employed in forestry (including afforestation) you don't need a site licence to temporarily live in a caravan on a piece of land for a particular season.

data.info:
You will not need planning permission if on 5 March 2018 the building was only used as any of the following:

  • house
  • shop
  • financial and professional services
  • restaurant or cafe
  • offices
  • betting office
  • payday loan shop
  • laundrette

You will not need planning permission if on 5 March 2018 the building was used as any of the following:

  • in mixed-used combining 2 or more of: a shop, financial and professional services, a restaurant or cafe, offices, a betting office, a payday loan shop, or a laundrette
  • in mixed-use combining a house with 1 or more of: a shop, financial and professional services, a restaurant or cafe, offices, a betting office, a payday loan shop, or a laundrette

Development of this type always needs prior approval.

data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A.1 (f)(i)
data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
If the tree is being cut down for any other reason other than to allow the growth of other trees (most likely as part of a managed woodland) then you must provide notice to your local planning authority before proceeding.

Your local planning authority then has a period of 6 weeks (from the date of the notice) to respond and/or to place a protection order on that tree if required. If they do not respond within 6 weeks, you then have a legal right to proceed with the works, provided they are completed within a period of 2 years from the same date.

It is a criminal offence to cut down the tree for any other reason. If you are unsure, we strongly recommend providing 6 weeks notice to your local planning authority anyway.
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Tree Preservation)(England) Regulations 2012 Part 3 Section 15 (d)(ii)

It is not always obvious which side of a house is the front (the principal elevation).

The front of the house usually faces a road and contains any architectural features such as bay windows or porches.

data.info:
In the case of works to a tree that are urgently needed to avoid the risk of serious harm, and it is not possible to notify your local planning authority before carrying out the works, you must notify them as soon as possible after carrying out the work.

If it is (within reason) possible to temporarily make the tree safe, you must do so, then notify your local planning authority at least 5 working days before commencing the works.

It may be a criminal offence if you do works to the tree and fail to notify your local planning authority at or before the required time.

data.howMeasured:
The 'original house' is the house as it was when first built, regardless of when that was.

'Additions' include any enclosed structure in the grounds of the house, including garden sheds, greenhouses, other storage buildings, swimming pools or other pools or containers (such as tanks).

The 'curtilage' of a house is the enclosed space of ground and buildings immediately surrounding a dwelling-house, that is used as part of the enjoyment of that home. In many cases this is the entire area within the property boundary, but not always. In some cases, the total property may include areas of land that are not part of the curtilage of the house. This can sometimes be an area where interpretation is needed. If you are unsure, you should consult a professional and/or apply for Certificate of Lawfulness before proceeding with any works.

data.howMeasured:
This is measured as if there were an imaginary line across the front of the principal elevation of the house, extending all the way to the property boundary. You should not include bay windows, protrusions or previous additions.

The 'front' in this case means the principal elevation. The principal elevation usually means that side of the house which fronts (directly or at an angle) the main highway serving the house (the main highway will be the one that sets the postcode for the house concerned). It will usually (but not always) contain the main architectural features such as main bay windows or a porch serving the main entrance to the house.

In some cases (for example a house on a corner, or a house that appears to face sideway) it may not be clear which is the principal elevation. If unsure, you should consult your local planning authority.

data.info: Works that would involve significant excavation or engineering works (such as underpinning) are likely to require planning permission.

data.policyRef: [Eatherley vs London Borough of Camden](https://www.casemine.com/judgement/uk/5a8ff7c760d03e7f57eb2034)
data.howMeasured: Basement extensions are not explicitly covered by the legislation determining what is 'permitted development'. For some time many planning authorities treated them as extensions covered by The General Permitted Development Order 2015. However, in 2016 the case of [Eatherley vs London Borough of Camden](https://www.casemine.com/judgement/uk/5a8ff7c760d03e7f57eb2034) set a precedent that significant excavations and engineering works (such as temporary propping and underpinning) constitute a "a separate activity of substance" in their own right.

data.info:
You need to serve a notice on your neighbour and either get their agreement or failing that instruct a surveyor to issue a party wall award for any work to:

  • the wall between terraced and semi-detached houses, or
  • a shared party structure

This does not apply to works such as:

  • drilling into the wall internally to fit kitchen units or shelving
  • having the wall plastered
  • adding or replacing electrical wiring or sockets

The notice must include full details of the works you are doing, give your neighbour at least 2 months' notice of the works starting and say what, if any, access you need across their property to get the works completed.

data.info:
Within Greater London, the use of homes as temporary sleeping accommodation requires planning permission. This applies even if only part of the premises is used as temporary sleeping accommodation.

However planning permission is not required if two tests are met:

(a) it is used for temporary sleeping accommodation for 90 or fewer nights in a calendar year.

(b) the person who provided the sleeping accommodation was liable to pay council tax (which would therefore include people who are liable to council tax but are in receipt of a discount) during the time when the property was used as temporary sleeping accommodation.
data.text: Over a calendar year, is the property used as a holiday let for more than 90 nights?
data.policyRef: Section 25A of the Deregulation Act 2015 Deregulation Act 2015 (legislation.gov.uk)
data.howMeasured: When calculating whether it was used for more than 90 nights, you count the number of nights of use as temporary sleeping accommodation, and the number of nights (if any) of each previous use of the premises as temporary sleeping accommodation in the same calendar year.

data.howMeasured:
This includes the volume of any roof extensions, additions or enlargements (for example, changes to the shape of the roof) that have been made to the house since it was first built, or since 1 July 1948 if the house was built before that date.

You can ignore any roof extensions, additions or enlargements that are being removed as part of these changes.

When making this calculation, you should include all extensions, additions or enlargements, regardless of whether they were built with planning permission or under permitted development.

This is measured from the face of the face of the dormer to the outer edge of the tiles or equivalent roof surface.

Do not include any guttering that sticks out beyond the roof slope. This applies on all outer edges of the roof.

On 'L-shaped' dormers, it does not apply to the part of the dormer that joins onto the protruding part of the house. But it does apply at the far end edge of that protrusion.

The 'original eaves' mean the eaves of the roof as it was when it was first built or as they were in July 1948 if built before then.

data.description: The front of the house is usually the side with the front door on.
data.howMeasured:
This is measured as if there were an imaginary line across the front of the principal elevation of the house, extending all the way to the property boundary. You should not include bay windows, protrusions or previous additions.

The 'front' in this case means the principal elevation. The principal elevation usually means that side of the house which fronts (directly or at an angle) the main highway serving the house (the main highway will be the one that sets the postcode for the house concerned). It will usually (but not always) contain the main architectural features such as main bay windows or a porch serving the main entrance to the house.

In some cases (for example a house on a corner, or a house that appears to face sideway) it may not be clear which is the principal elevation. If unsure, you should consult your local planning authority.

data.howMeasured:
A detached house does not join any other properties.

A semi-detached house joins only one other property which, in turn, does not adjoin any other properties. So together, the 2 properties form a pair.

A terraced house is a building that forms part of a row of 3 or more adjoining properties. This includes buildings at the end of the row (an end terrace).

data.description: This include buildings on other sites operated by the same farmer or farming business.
data.howMeasured:
'Holding' here is defined as the 'agricultural unit'.

“Agricultural unit” means agricultural land occupied as a unit for the purposes of agriculture, including:

(a) any dwelling or other building on that land occupied for the purpose of farming the land by the person who occupies the unit, or

( b ) any dwelling on that land occupied by a farmworker.

So the agricultural unit can include both farm buildings, farmland and farmhouses operated as a farming business. This is not limited to a single site or a single property title. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are physically connected they will be considered as being part of one 'agricultural unit'. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are not physically connected, it is very probable that they will also be considered as a single agricultural unit, depending on their proximity. If in doubt contact your local planning authority before continuing with any works.

data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
Planning permission is always needed to change the use of many types of property, such as waste disposal facilities and storage or distribution buildings.

The exceptions to this are changes that do not represent a 'material' change in the use of the property because the new use is within the same use class, or material changes that fall within the General Permitted Development Order.

The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any prior extension that may have been added to the house. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

  • in mixed-use combining a house with 1 or more of: a shop, financial and professional services, a restaurant or cafe, offices, a betting office, a payday loan shop, or a laundrette

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is protected by a Tree Preservation Order (TPO), the following works need consent from your local planning authority:

  • cutting down
  • cutting roots
  • topping
  • lopping
  • uprooting
  • wilful damage (including to roots)
  • wilful destruction

It is an offence to carry out any of these actions without consent from your local planning authority.

data.howMeasured:
Members of a 'family' or 'household' are those who are related, married or living together as if they were married. This would include children who are legally adopted.

Housemates who are not related, or lodgers living with landlords would be considered as comprising multiple households.

In some rare cases (for example religious communities) it may be possible that a number of unrelated people who are not in a partnering relationship may live together in such a way as might be regarded as a single household

data.howMeasured:
This includes the volume of any roof extensions, additions or enlargements (for example, changes to the shape of the roof) that have been made to the house since it was first built, or since 1 July 1948 if the house was built before that date.

You can ignore any roof extensions, additions or enlargements that are being removed as part of these changes.

When making this calculation, you should include all extensions, additions or enlargements, regardless of whether they were built with planning permission or under permitted development.

A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) that is occupied by six people or fewer falls into use class C4. This use class benefits from General Permitted Development Rights that permit certain kinds of development to be carried out without planning permission.

An HMO occupied by 7 or more people falls into its own 'Sui Generis' use class and therefore planning permission will be required.

data.info:
In the case of a tree that is in a conservation area with a trunk diameter greater than 75mm, you must provide notice to your local planning authority before proceeding with any of the following actions:

  • cutting roots
  • topping
  • lopping

It is an offence to carry out any of these actions without providing notice to your local planning authority. Your local planning authority then has a period of 6 weeks (from the date of the notice) to respond and/ or to place a protection order on that tree if required. If they do not respond within 6 weeks, you then have a legal right to proceed with the works, provided they are completed within a period of 2 years from the same date.
data.text: What is the diameter of the tree trunk?
data.policyRef: Town and Country Planning Act 1990 Part 8 (Section 211)
data.howMeasured: Trunk diameter is measured around the bark of the trunk at a height of 1.5m above the natural ground level. If the tree has more than one stem at this height, you should measure the diameter of the largest stem at that level.

Planning permission is needed to use a residential annexe as a self-contained dwelling or a holiday let.

data.info:
The owner should apply to the local planning authority for prior approval before starting work.

The local authority team will make an assessment based on:

  • the design and appearance of the scheme
  • any possible contamination
  • any impact on light, views, privacy, air traffic or defence

You will need to provide your local planning authority with a report that shows how you will manage the construction of the development. This should include the proposed hours of work and how any impact of noise, dust, vibration and traffic on people who live next door will be mitigated.

data.howMeasured:
In principle, if you have not heard back from your local planning authority within 42 days of submitting a valid application for prior approval, it can be deemed that you do not need prior approval.

However, if you have not heard back about your prior approval application we recommend you contact your local planning authority before starting work.

data.info:
Within Greater London, the use of homes as temporary sleeping accommodation requires planning permission. This applies even if only part of the premises is used as temporary sleeping accommodation.

However planning permission is not required if two tests are met:

(a) it is used for temporary sleeping accommodation for 90 or fewer nights in a calendar year.

(b) the person who provided the sleeping accommodation was liable to pay council tax (which would therefore include people who are liable to council tax but are in receipt of a discount) during the time when the property was used as temporary sleeping accommodation.
data.text: Over a calendar year, is the property used as a holiday let for more than 90 nights?
data.policyRef: Section 25A of the Deregulation Act 2015 Deregulation Act 2015 (legislation.gov.uk)
data.howMeasured: When calculating whether it was used for more than 90 nights, you count the number of nights of use as temporary sleeping accommodation, and the number of nights (if any) of each previous use of the premises as temporary sleeping accommodation in the same calendar year.

data.info:
Your home is a house in multiple occupation (HMO) if both of the following apply:

  • at least 3 tenants live there, forming more than 1 household
  • you share toilet, bathroom or kitchen facilities with other tenants

Your home is a large HMO if both of the following apply:

  • at least 5 tenants live there, forming more than 1 household
  • you share toilet, bathroom or kitchen facilities with other tenants

A household is either a single person or members of the same family who live together. A family includes people who are:

  • married or living together - including people in same-sex relationships

data.notes:
The 1960 act says that use of a caravan within the curtilage of a house is permitted provided it is incidental. However, the meaning most councils seem to work to is actually 'ancilliary'

We *think* the reason for this is that that simply positioning a caravan on the site does not involve construction work, and therefore , provided no separate self-contained dwelling is being created (which would be a material change in use), no actual development is taking place.

data.info: In Millington v Secretary of State for Environment [2000] processing was an ancillary use to growing the raw material to make the product marketable or disposable for profit (in this case making wine into grapes). So, if you carry out an ancillary activity to process a raw material you do not need permission. The scale and proportion of the acitivty in relation to the original use of the land is an important factor. If you are unsure whether the use is ancillary we recomend you submit a Lawful Development Certificate.

Within Greater London, the use of homes as temporary sleeping accommodation requires planning permission. This applies even if only part of the premises is used as temporary sleeping accommodation.

However planning permission is not required if two tests are met:

(a) it is used for temporary sleeping accommodation for 90 or fewer nights in a calendar year.

(b) the person who provided the sleeping accommodation was liable to pay council tax (which would therefore include people who are liable to council tax but are in receipt of a discount) during the time when the property was used as temporary sleeping accommodation.

data.info:
The owner should apply to the local planning authority for prior approval before starting work.

The local authority team will make an assessment based on:

  • the design and appearance of the scheme
  • any possible contamination
  • any impact on light, views, privacy, air traffic or defence

You will need to provide your local planning authority with a report that shows how you will manage the construction of the development. This should include the proposed hours of work and how any impact of noise, dust, vibration and traffic on people who live next door will be mitigated.

data.howMeasured:
In principle, if you have not heard back from your local planning authority within 42 days of submitting a valid application for prior approval, you can assume that you do not need prior approval.

If you have not heard back about your prior approval application we recommend that you contact your local planning authority before starting work.

data.policyRef: [General Permitted Development Order 2015 S.2 P.1 A.1 (c)](  https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/596/schedule/2/part/1)
data.howMeasured:
The highest part of the roof is taken as the height of the ridge line of the main roof of the existing house (even though there may be other ridge lines at a lower level) OR the height of the highest roof where roofs on a building are flat.

When considering the height of the highest part of the roof of the existing house, you can ignore chimneys, firewalls, parapet walls and other protrusions, which might be higher than the main roof ridge line. However, such protrusions on the new extension should be factored into its height.

data.info: You'll need planning permission for building agricultural buildings if the land does not comprise an agricultural unit of 5 hectares or more.
data.text: Is the property used as a farm, nursery or other agricultural premises?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 6, Class A
data.howMeasured:
Land or buildings in agricultural use includes horticulture, fruit growing, seed growing, dairy farming, the use of land as grazing land, meadow land, osier land, market gardens and nursery grounds, the use of land for woodlands where connected to the farming of land for other agricultural purposes and the breeding and keeping of livestock (including any creature kept for the production of food, wool, skins or fur, or for the purpose of its use in the farming of land).

The management of land for sporting shooting is not considered to be agriculture but a recreational pursuit, see the decision of the House of Lords (Earl of Normanton v. Giles 1980).

If the main purpose of new building is not 'reasonably necessary' for agriculture or forestry, and is more to do with recreation (e.g. recreational shooting) then permitted development rights do not apply and you'll need planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
This includes the volume of any roof extensions, additions or enlargements (for example, changes to the shape of the roof) that have been added to the house since it was first built, or since 1 July 1948 if the house was built before that date.

You can ignore any roof extensions, additions or enlargements that are being removed as part of these changes.

When making this calculation, you should include all extensions, additions or enlargements, regardless of whether they were built with planning permission or under permitted development.

data.text: Have any other buildings on the holding already been converted to a commercial use?
data.description: This include buildings on other sites operated by the same farmer or farming business.
data.howMeasured:
This does not include any agricultural buildings converted to homes.

'Holding' here is defined as the 'agricultural unit'.

“Agricultural unit” means agricultural land occupied as a unit for the purposes of agriculture, including:

(a) any dwelling or other building on that land occupied for the purpose of farming the land by the person who occupies the unit, or

( b ) any dwelling on that land occupied by a farmworker;

So the agricultural unit can include both farm buildings, farmland and farmhouses operated as a farming business. This is not limited to a single site or a single property title. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are physically connected they will be considered as being part of one 'agricultural unit'. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are not physically connected, it is very probable that they will also be considered as a single agricultural unit, depending on their proximity. If in doubt contact your local planning authority before continuing with any works.
