data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this dimension includes any prior extension that may have been added to the house. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is 'stepped', the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

data.text: How do the occupants of the home live together?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) (Amendment) (England) Regulations 2020 (SI 757)
data.howMeasured:
Members of a 'household' are those who are related, married or living together as if they were married. This would include children who are legally adopted.

Housemates who are not related, or lodgers living with landlords would be considered as comprising multiple households.

In some rare cases (for example religious communities) it may be possible that a number of unrelated people who are not in a partnering relationship may live together in such a way as might be regarded as a single household.

You should ignore any extensions or projections that have been added since the property was first built.

data.info:
Planning permission is not needed to use an outbuilding for a use that is additional to (but supports) the use of the main house as a place to live (for example, a shed, store or gym). This is known as an 'incidental' use.

Planning permission is needed if any outbuildings would be used for an activity that would normally be associated with the main use of the home as a place to live, for example sleeping accommodation or a kitchen. This is known as an 'ancilliary use'

Planning permission is also needed if the changes would involve creating a new, self-contained dwelling.

data.info:
A dwelling occupied by more than 3 people who are not from the same household (for example not a family) is a House in Multiple Occupation (HMO).

HMOs with 3 to 6 occupants fall under use class C4.

HMOs with 7 or more occupants are 'large HMOs' and fall under their own 'Sui Generis' use class. ]Conversion of a family home (C3) to a small HMO (C4) is permitted development, and therefore does not need planning permission.

Conversion of a family home to a large HMO always needs planning permission.

data.info:
You’ll need planning permission unless the building has been vacant for a continuous period of at least 3 months before your application for Prior Approval.

Even if you do not need to apply for planning permission, converting a business or commercial use to homes will require you to apply for Prior Approval, with respect to:

  • Transport impacts
  • Contamination risks
  • Flooding risks
  • Noise impact
  • The impact on the character and use of a Conservation Area (if the property is in one)
  • Provision of adequate natural light
  • The impact of surrounded uses on future occupiers
  • Loss of any nurseries or health centres.
  • Fire safety
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 3, Class MA
data.howMeasured: Prior Approval means that you must seek approval from the local planning authority that specific elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed.

data.info:

Even if you do not need to apply for planning permission, converting a business or commercial use to homes will require you to apply for Prior Approval, with respect to:

data.howMeasured:
The highest part of the roof is taken as the height of the ridgeline of the main roof of the existing house (even though there may be other ridge lines at a lower level) or the height of the highest roof where roofs on a building are flat.

You can ignore chimneys, firewalls, parapet walls and other parts that stick out unless the highest part of the house is part of an enlargement added after the original construction, in which case the height of any protrusions needs to be included.

data.info:
You will need planning permission for any outbuilding unless it is used for purposes that are incidental to the enjoyment of the house, or for its maintenance.

Uses that are ancillary will always need planning permission.

The use of an outbuilding for a purpose that is incidental to (supports) the enjoyment of the property as a home would not usually be considered a material change of use and would not need planning permission.
data.text: What additional space will the outbuilding provide?
data.policyRef: The Town The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class E
data.howMeasured:
'Incidental' means a secondary, additional function that most houses do not create space for, but supports the enjoyment of the home. This secondary activity is only happening there because the house is there.

'Ancilliary' means providing extra space for the same kind of activities that you would normally expect to do in a home, such as cooking, eating, sleeping etc.

You will not need planning permission if on 5 March 2018 the building was used as any of the following:

  • in mixed-used combining 2 or more of: a shop, financial and professional services, a restaurant or cafe, offices, a betting office, a payday loan shop, or a laundrette

You'll need planning permission if building within the agricultural unit have already been converted:

(i)since 20th March 2013; or

(ii)where development under Class S.2.P.3.Q begins after 20th March 2023, during the period which is 10 years before the date development under Class Q begins.
data.text: Have any other agricultural buildings on the holding been erected, extended or altered since March 20th 2013?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 3, Class S.
data.howMeasured:
Holding' here is defined as the 'agricultural unit'.

“Agricultural unit” means agricultural land occupied as a unit for the purposes of agriculture, including:

(a) any dwelling or other building on that land occupied for the purpose of farming the land by the person who occupies the unit, or

( b ) any dwelling on that land occupied by a farmworker.

So the agricultural unit can include both farm buildings, farmland and farmhouses operated as a farming business. This is not limited to a single site or a single property title. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are physically connected they will be considered as being part of one 'agricultural unit'. If the farmer or farming business operates a number of sites that are not physically connected, it is very probable that they will also be considered as a single agricultural unit, depending on their proximity. If in doubt contact your local planning authority before continuing with any works.

data.text: Is the property on designated land?
data.howMeasured: Designated land (also known as 'Article (2) 3' land) is any of: land in a Conservation Area; land in an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty; Land affected by the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981, land in the Broads, land in a National Park, or land that is part of a World Heritage Site.

data.info:
Using a caravan for forestry purposes (such as storage, shelter for workers or as an office) falls outside planning controls if it is not used for residential use.

According to the Caravan Sites Act 1968, the legal definition of a caravan includes mobile homes and self-built structures.

Under this definition, the caravan does not need to have wheels if all of the following apply:

  • less than 60 feet long, 20 feet wide and 10 feet high
  • can be delivered in 2 sections (or fewer) by lorry
  • can be moved in one piece along a road when assembled
data.text: Can the movable building be transported in no more than 2 sections by a lorry?
data.policyRef: Caravan Sites Act 1968 Chapter 52, Part III, Section 13
data.howMeasured:
A caravan is defined as a structure designed or adapted for human habitation.

It is made of a maximum of 2 sections that can be joined together on a site.

A caravan can be moved by road from one place to another. For example, being towed or on a trailer.

However, if your structure cannot lawfully be moved on a road when built it does not mean it is not a caravan.

Caravans must be less than:

  • 20 metres (65.6 feet) long. This excludes any drawbars that connect the caravan to the vehicle that pulls it
  • 6.8 metres (22.3 feet) wide
  • 3.05 metres (10 feet) high. This is measured from the floor to ceiling inside the caravan

Uses that are ancillary will always need planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
'Incidental' means a secondary, additional function that most houses do not create space for, but supports the enjoyment of the home. This secondary activity is only happening there because the house is there.

'Ancilliary' means providing extra space for the kind of activities that you would normally expect to do in a home, such as cooking, eating and sleeping.

data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A.1
data.description: Include all bay windows, extensions, outbuildings and tanks added since the house was first built.
data.howMeasured:
The original house is the house as it was when first built, or as it stood on 1 July 1948 if was built before that date.

The 'curtilage' of a house is the enclosed space of ground and buildings immediately surrounding a dwelling-house, that is used as part of the enjoyment of that home. In many cases this is the entire area within the property boundary, but not always. In some cases, the total property may include areas of land that are not part of the curtilage of the house. This can sometimes be an area where interpretation is needed. If you are unsure, you should consult a professional and/or apply for a certificate of lawfulness before proceeding with any works.

'Additions' include any enclosed structure in the grounds of the house, including garden sheds, greenhouses, other storage buildings, swimming pools or other pools or containers (such as tanks).

data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A.
data.description: Measure from the highest point of the roof.
data.howMeasured:
The highest part of the roof is taken as either:

  • the height of the ridge line of the main roof of the existing house (even though there may be other ridge lines at a lower level)
  • the height of the highest roof where roofs on a building are flat

When considering the height of the highest part of the roof of the existing house, you can ignore chimneys, firewalls, parapet walls and other protrusions, which might be higher than the main roof ridge line. However, such protrusions on the new extension should be included in its height.

data.info: Letting a property for holiday lets may constitute a 'material change of use' (to holiday or leisure accommodation) if the additional traffic and possible lack of consideration for neighbours would lead to a change in the character of the area. This would need planning permission for a change of use to a guesthouse.
data.text: Are the additional comings and goings of tenants likely to be noticed by neighbours?
data.policyRef:
Town and Country Planning Act 1990, Section 55 

Moore v Secretary of State for Communities & Local Government
data.howMeasured:
There is no fixed definition of 'material change of use'.

In the case of Moore v Secretary of State for Communities & Local Government a precedent was set determining that the extent to which holiday lets may or may not represent a material change of use would be a 'matter of fact and degree'

This means it will depend on the circumstances, nature and extent of the activity, and its impacts on neighbours.

data.howMeasured:
A projection or 'outrigger' is a part of the building that protrudes beyond the main part of the house, forming an L or T shape. In some cases the house may have multiple rear projections, which may themselves even have further projections.

You should ignore any extensions or projections that have been added since the property was first built.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
A home of more than 3 people not from the same household (for example a family) is a house in multiple occupation (HMO).

HMOs with 3 to 6 people fall under use class C4. HMOs with 7 or more occupants are 'large HMOs' and fall under their own use class.

Conversion of a family home (C3) to a small HMO (C4) is permitted development and therefore does not need planning permission.

Conversion of a family home to a large HMO or to a guesthouse (C3) needs planning permission.

data.info:
A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) that is occupied by six people or fewer falls into use class C4. This use class benefits from General Permitted Development Rights that permit certain kinds of development to be carried out without planning permission.

An HMO occupied by 7 or more people falls into its own 'Sui Generis' use class and therefore planning permission will be required.

data.info:
Certain exceptions allow some works to be carried out to a protected tree without consent. If none of these exceptions apply, you will need to apply for consent to do works to a protected tree before commencing the work.

Dead trees

In the case of a tree that is dead the developer must provide at least 5 days' 'works to trees' notice to the local planning authority before works begin.

Dangerous trees

In cases where the works are urgently needed to remove an immediate risk of serious harm, and there is no reasonable way of making safe that risk for 5 days, then the developer must provide 'works to trees' notice to the local authority as soon as possible after carrying out the works.

The front of the house usually faces a road and contains any architectural features such as bay windows or porches.

data.howMeasured:
Is it a holiday let?

It is likely to be a holiday let if the following condiitons are met:

1) that the total of

(a) the number of nights of use and

(b) the number of nights of any previous use of the same premises as temporary sleeping accommodation in the same calendar year, is no greater than 90 nights;

2) for each night counted under (a), the person who provided the sleeping accommodation must be liable to pay council tax (which would therefore include people who are liable to council tax but are in receipt of a discount).

If these conditions are not met, the use of the building as temporary sleeping accommodation of residential properties creates a material change of use and needs planning permission.

The original house means the house has it was first built, or as it was on 1 July 1948 if it was built before then.

The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this dimension includes any prior extension that may have been added to the house. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

data.info:
Planning permission is not needed to use an outbuilding for a use that is additional to (but supports) the use of the main house as a place to live (for example, a shed, store or gym). This is known as an 'incidental' use.

Planning permission is needed if any outbuildings would be used for an activity that would normally be associated with the main use of the home as a place to live, for example sleeping accommodation or a kitchen. This is known as an 'ancilliary use'

Planning permission is also needed if the changes would involve creating a new, self-contained dwelling.

data.description: Select all that apply.
data.howMeasured:
'Incidental' means a secondary, additional function that most houses do not create space for, but supports the enjoyment of the home. This secondary activity is only happening there because the house is there.

'Ancilliary' means providing extra space for the same kind of activities that you would normally expect to do in a home, such as cooking, eating and sleeping.

A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) that is occupied by six people or fewer falls into use class C4. This use class benefits from General Permitted Development Rights that permit certain kinds of development to be carried out without planning permission.

An HMO occupied by 7 or more people falls into its own 'Sui Generis' use class and therefore planning permission will be required.

data.info:
Using a caravan for forestry purposes (such as storage, shelter for workers or as an office) falls outside planning controls if it is not used for residential use.

According to the Caravan Sites Act 1968, the legal definition of a caravan includes mobile homes and self-built structures.

Under this definition, the caravan does not need to have wheels if all of the following apply:

  • less than 60 feet long, 20 feet wide and 10 feet high
  • can be delivered in 2 sections (or fewer) by lorry
  • can be moved in one piece along a road when assembled
data.text: Is the immovable building more than 6m wide?
data.policyRef: Caravan Sites Act 1968 Chapter 52 13 (1,2)
data.howMeasured:
A caravan is defined as a structure designed or adapted for human habitation.

It is made of a maximum of 2 sections that can be joined together on a site.

A caravan can be moved by road from one place to another. For example, being towed or on a trailer.

However, if your structure cannot lawfully be moved on a road when built it does not mean it is not a caravan.

Caravans must be less than:

  • 20 metres (65.6 feet) long. This excludes any drawbars that connect the caravan to the vehicle that pulls it
  • 6.8 metres (22.3 feet) wide
  • 3.05 metres (10 feet) high. This is measured from the floor to ceiling inside the caravan

data.howMeasured:
A projection or 'outrigger' is a part of the building that protrudes out, so the building forms a T or L shape. Some houses may have more than one. In some cases projections may themselves have a projection, creating a stepped shape. Note that this question applies only to the house as it was originally built, not including any extensions that have been added since.

The original house means the house as it was when it was first built, or as it stood on 1 July 1948 if it was built before that date.

data.policyRef: Eatherley vs London Borough of Camden
data.howMeasured: Basement extensions are not explicitly covered by the legislation determining what is 'permitted development'. For some time many planning authorities treated them as extensions covered by The General Permitted Development Order 2015. However, in 2016 the case of Eatherley vs London Borough of Camden set a precedent that significant excavations and engineering works (such as temporary propping and underpinning) constitute a "a separate activity of substance" in their own right.

data.text: Are any of the neighbouring properties in residential use?

This includes homes, care homes and residential accommodation that may be part of a school, college or hospital. Also answer yes to this question if any adjacent land has been granted planning permission for residential use but has not yet been developed.

You will need planning permission if the greenhouse is:

  • used by non-paying members of a club

Using the greenhouse for commercial use may not need planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
Private use means use only by the owner as part of their enjoyment of the property.

Public use means open for use to members of the public or members of a club (whether on a free or paying basis).

Commercial use means use as part of a business or on a paid or rented basis.

data.info:
Planning permission may be required if, by letting the property to more, or fewer people than before, the use class of the property changes from a Large HMO (Sui Generis) to a small HMO (C4).

If you are not sure whether if it has permission to be used as a Large HMO, we recommend applying for a Lawful Development Certificate to confirm that the current use of the property is lawful.
data.text: Is the current use of the property as a Large House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) lawful?
data.policyRef: Town and Country Planning Act 1990 Section 171B, First Secretary of State v Arun District Council & Anor
data.description: For example, as a result of a previous planning consent, or because it has been in that use for more than 4 years without any enforcement action being taken.
data.howMeasured:
A Small HMO is a property occuped by 1-6 people who are not related, and are not living together as a single family, usually with some shared facilities.

A Large HMO is a property occupied by 7+ people who are not related to each other, and are not living together as a single family, usually with some shared facilities.

data.info:
You will need planning permission if the construction of storage, waste or other facilities:

  • extend beyond the curtilage of the existing building
  • are in front of a wall that forms the front (principal elevation) of the existing building
  • are in front of a wall that faces a highway and forms a side elevation of the existing building

Development of this type always needs prior approval.
data.text: Will the facilities be entirely within the curtilage of the building?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 20, Class AA.
data.howMeasured: The curtilage means the building and the immediate area of land that it is part of (if it has one), such as a driveway, yard or garden. It is not necessarily the same as the property boundary, if the property includes multiple buildings, or areas of land that are not part of the curtilage of any building.

data.info:
You'll need planning permission for the construction of any building or structure on agricultral land if the building or structure are not for agricultural purposes.

If planning permission is not needed, you will still need to apply to your local authority for Prior Approval before proceeding. This is a form of planning consent that only focuses on specific issues. In this case, it is focused on the siting, design and external appearance of the building.
data.text: What is the purpose of the new buildings?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 6, Class A
data.howMeasured:
Agricultural purposes includes horticulture, fruit growing, seed growing, dairy farming, the breeding and keeping of livestock (including any creature kept for the production of food, wool, skins or fur or for the purpose of its use in the farming of land). The use of land as grazing land, meadow land, osier land, market gardens and nursery grounds, and the use of land for woodlands where that use is ancillary to the farming of land for other agricultural purposes, and agricultural shall be construed accordingly.

The management of land for sporting shooting is not considered to be agriculture but a recreational pursuit, see the decision of the House of Lords (Earl of Normanton v. Giles 1980).

If the primary purpose of new building is not reasonably necessary for the purposes of agriculture or forestry, and is required to enhance or manage the use of the land for recreational purposes (e.g. recreational shooting) then permitted development rights do not apply and planning permission is needed.

data.info:
You will not need planning permission if on 5 March 2018 the building was only used as any of the following:

  • house
  • shop
  • financial and professional services
  • restaurant or cafe
  • offices
  • betting office
  • payday loan shop
  • laundrette

You will not need planning permission if on 5 March 2018 the building was used as any of the following:

  • in mixed-used combining 2 or more of: a shop, financial and professional services, a restaurant or cafe, offices, a betting office, a payday loan shop, or a laundrette
  • in mixed-use combining a house with 1 or more of: a shop, financial and professional services, a restaurant or cafe, offices, a betting office, a payday loan shop, or a laundrette

Development of this type always needs prior approval.

The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any previous extensions. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) that is occupied by six people or fewer falls into use class C4. This use class benefits from General Permitted Development Rights that permit certain kinds of development to be carried out without planning permission.

An HMO occupied by 7 or more people falls into its own 'Sui Generis' use class and therefore planning permission will be required.

data.info:
Structures that extend 3m or less from the respective rear wall of a terraced house may not need planning permission.

Structures that extend between 3 and 6m from the rear wall may not require planning permission but will need prior approval.

Otherwise, you will need planning permission.
data.text: How far does the new extension extend beyond the back wall of the original house?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A.1 (f)(i)
data.howMeasured:
The depth of an extension is measured from the external face of the rear wall of the original house. So this includes any prior extension that may have been added to the house. It does not include any guttering or barge boards.

If the rear of the original house is stepped, the extension should be measured from each part of the rear walls you are extending from, even if it is not the rearmost part of the original house.

The original house is the house as it was first built, or as it was in 1948 (if it was built before 1948) not including any subsequent additions or alterations.

data.info:
Development under Class AA is permitted only on the condition that before commencing with the works, the owner should apply to the local planning authority for prior approval. The local authority team will make an assessment on the basis of the design and appearance of the scheme, of any impacts on light, views, privacy, air traffic or defence.

You will also need to provide your local planning authority with a report for the management of the construction of the development, which sets out the proposed development hours of operation and how any adverse impact of noise, dust, vibration and traffic on adjoining owners or occupiers will be mitigated.

data.info:
Using a caravan for forestry purposes (such as storage, shelter for workers or as an office) falls outside planning controls if it is not used for residential use.

According to the Caravan Sites Act 1968, the legal definition of a caravan includes mobile homes and self-built structures.

Under this definition, the caravan does not need to have wheels if all of the following apply:

  • less than 60 feet long, 20 feet wide and 10 feet high
  • can be delivered in 2 sections (or fewer) by lorry
  • can be moved in one piece along a road when assembled
data.text: Is the immovable building more than 18m long?
data.policyRef: Caravan Sites Act 1968 Chapter 52, Part III, Section 13
data.howMeasured:
A caravan is defined as a structure designed or adapted for human habitation.

It is made of a maximum of 2 sections that can be joined together on a site.

A caravan can be moved by road from one place to another. For example, being towed or on a trailer.

However, if your structure cannot lawfully be moved on a road when built it does not mean it is not a caravan.

Caravans must be less than:

  • 20 metres (65.6 feet) long. This excludes any drawbars that connect the caravan to the vehicle that pulls it
  • 6.8 metres (22.3 feet) wide
  • 3.05 metres (10 feet) high. This is measured from the floor to ceiling inside the caravan

data.info:
You will need planning permission if the sauna is:

  • open for use by the community
  • used by non-paying members of a club

An outbuilding that will be used for a use that is additional to (but supports) the use of the main house as a place to live (for example, a shed, store or gym) does not require planning permission. This is known as an 'incidental' use.
data.text: How will the sauna be used?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Section 2, Part 1. Class E.1
data.howMeasured:
Private use means use only by the owner as part of their enjoyment of the property.

Public use means open for use to members of the public or members of a club (whether on a free or paying basis).

Commercial use means use as part of a business or on a paid or rented basis.

data.info:
Members of a household are people who are related, married or living together as if they were married. This includes children who are legally adopted.

Housemates who are not related, or lodgers living with landlords would be considered as multiple households.

In some cases (for example some religious communities) it may be possible that a number of unrelated people who are not in a relationship may live together in such a way as might be regarded as a single household.

data.info:
A House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) that is occupied by six people or fewer falls into use class C4. This use class benefits from General Permitted Development Rights that permit certain kinds of development to be carried out without planning permission.

An HMO occupied by 7 or more people falls into its own 'Sui Generis' use class and therefore planning permission will be required.

data.info:
Using a caravan for forestry purposes (such as storage, shelter for workers or as an office) falls outside planning controls if it is not used for residential use.

According to the Caravan Sites Act 1968, the legal definition of a caravan includes mobile homes and self-built structures.

Under this definition, the caravan does not need to have wheels if all of the following apply:

  • less than 60 feet long, 20 feet wide and 10 feet high
  • can be delivered in 2 sections (or fewer) by lorry
  • can be moved in one piece along a road when assembled
data.policyRef: Caravan Sites Act 1968 Chapter 52, Part III, Section 13
data.howMeasured:
A caravan is defined as a structure designed or adapted for human habitation.

It is made of a maximum of 2 sections that can be joined together on a site.

A caravan can be moved by road from one place to another. For example, being towed or on a trailer.

However, if your structure cannot lawfully be moved on a road when built it does not mean it is not a caravan.

Caravans must be less than:

  • 20 metres (65.6 feet) long. This excludes any drawbars that connect the caravan to the vehicle that pulls it
  • 6.8 metres (22.3 feet) wide
  • 3.05 metres (10 feet) high. This is measured from the floor to ceiling inside the caravan

data.info:
In the case of flats, adding a deck or platform that would materially affect the external appearance of the building need planning permission.

A deck that does not materially affect the external appearance of the building may not be considered to be development (as defined by Section 55 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990) and therefore may not need planning permission.

data.policyRef: Town and Country Planning Act 1990, Part 3, Section 55

data.description: Public highways include public roads, pavements, paths and bridleways.
data.howMeasured:
Public highways include public roads, pavements, paths and bridleways.

It is not always obvious which side of a house is the front (the principal elevation).

In most cases, it is the side with the front or main door on.

The front of the house usually faces a road and contains any architectural features such as bay windows or porches.

If you are unsure, you should consult your local planning authority.

data.info:
Development is permitted only on the condition that before commencing with the works, the owner should apply to the local planning authority for 'Prior Approval'. The local authority team will make an assessment on the basis of the design and appearance of the scheme, any possible contamination, any impacts on light, views, privacy, air traffic or defence. You will also need to provide your local planning authority with a report for the management of the construction of the development, which sets out the proposed development hours of operation and how any adverse impact of noise, dust, vibration and traffic on adjoining owners or occupiers will

be mitigated.
data.text: Does the design seek to minimise negative impacts on light, views and privacy for neighbours as far as possible?
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 Schedule 2, Part 20, Class AB.
data.howMeasured: In principle, if you have not heard back from your local planning authority within 42 days of submitting a valid application for prior approval, it can be deemed that Prior Approval is not required. However, this assumes the information was valid. If you have not heard back about your Prior Approval application it is strongly recommended you contact them before proceeding with works.

data.title: Upload roof plan after
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015
data.description: This plan should show the roof of the building after the works.
data.howMeasured:
Your roof plan must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:100 or 1:50 at A3 or A4 size
  • Have a scale bar
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

You should include

  • Materials Label any materials or features that are relevant for the proposed changes

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the proposed changes.

data.title: Upload site plan after
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015 (as amended)
data.description: This is sometimes also referred to as a Block Plan. It should show the entire site as it looks after the works.
data.howMeasured:
Your site plan must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:500 or 1:200 at A3 or A4 size
  • Have a scale bar
  • Show the direction of North
  • Have a unique drawing reference number
  • Be based on an up-to-date map or survey

It should include

  • Buildings including outbuildings and nearby neighbouring buildings
  • Trees on or adjoining the site
  • Roads
  • Public footpaths or rights of way
  • Hard surfaces such as patios or decks
  • Boundaries such as walls or fences

If you are showing the red site outline on your drawing, please make sure it matches the red line boundary you drew earlier.

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the changes.

Any works that change the way the property looks from above, such as adding an extension, will require an existing and proposed roof plan to be submitted.

If this was already shown on another drawing you can re-add the same drawing here.
data.title: Outbuilding roof plan
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015
data.description: Upload a plan showing the roof of the outbuilding
data.howMeasured:
Your roof plan must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:100 or 1:50 at A3 or A4 size
  • Have a scale bar
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the changes.

data.info: Any works that change the way the property looks from above, such as adding an extension, will require an existing and proposed roof plan to be submitted.
data.title: Upload roof plan before
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015
data.description: This plan should show the roof of the building before the works.
data.howMeasured:
Your roof plan must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:100 or 1:50 at A3 or A4 size
  • Have a scale bar
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

You should include

  • Materials Label any materials or features that are relevant for the proposed changes

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the changes.

data.title: Unit plans after
data.description: Upload plans clearly showing the units clearly outlined and labelled, as it is after the changes.
data.howMeasured:
Your unit plan must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:100 or 1:50 at A3 or A4 size
  • Have a scale bar
  • Show the direction of North
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

It should show

  • Units Outline and label (if appropriate) the current unit or units

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the changes.

data.text: Do these plans show the entire property?
data.description: This includes all buildings on the property, and the entire area within the property boundary

data.text: Would you like to upload any other additional drawings or documents?
data.description: If you wish to, you can provide your planning officer with additional information to support your application

data.title: Upload a section drawing showing the solar panels
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015 (as amended)
data.howMeasured:
Your sections must

  • Be drawn to scale Usually 1:100 or 1:50 at A3 or A4 size
  • Have a scale bar
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

You should include

  • The outline of the roof and the solar panels You do not need to show the inside of the building unless it is relevant.

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the proposed changes.

data.title: What do these documents show?
data.description: Please provide a brief description of the additional documents you have uploaded

data.text: Where have the solar panels been installed?
data.description: Select all that apply

data.title: Upload solar panel detail
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) 2015 (as amended)
data.description: Upload a detail drawing showing how the solar panels fix to the building
data.howMeasured:
Your detail must

  • Be drawn to scale
  • Have a scale bar
  • Have a unique drawing reference number

Your application may be marked as invalid if the drawings do not clearly and accurately describe the site and the proposed changes.

data.title: We would love to hear your feedback.
data.description:
You can now close this window, or start a new application.

If you have found this service useful, or would like to suggest a way we can improve it, please let us know using the feedback link at the bottom of the page.

data.content:
How to apply for Prior Approval

You can submit an application for Prior Approval in the same way that you would submit a planning application, for example, by using the Planning Portal. Find out more information about Prior Approval (opens in new tab).

This service will require you to submit drawings of your proposals, and includes a small planning fee.

This exemption also applies to applications for reserved matters on a granted outline planning permission.

You can only apply for one resubmission for the whole or part of a site, irrespective of multiple withdrawals, granting or refusal of planning permission.

data.info:
There is no fee for applications if the work is only to provide:

  • access to (or within) the home for a disabled resident or
  • facilities to ensure a disabled person's safety, health or comfort

If the application also includes any works that are not for these purposes, then the fee exemption does not apply.

There is no fee exemption for applications to build a new home for someone with a disability.

  • Section 6 of the Equalities Act 2010 defines a disabled person over 18 years old
  • Part 3 of the Children Act 1989 defines a disabled child

data.info:
There is no fee for applications if the work is only to provide:

  • access to (or within) the home for a disabled resident or
  • facilities to ensure a disabled person's safety, health or comfort

If the application also includes any works that are not for these purposes, then the fee exemption does not apply.

There is no fee exemption for applications to build a new home for someone with a disability.
data.text: Are the works being done to provide access for a disabled resident, or to improve their safety, health or comfort?
data.policyRef: UK Statutory Instruments 2012 No. 2920 Regulation 4, Equalities Act 2010, Section 6 and Children Act 1989, Part 3
data.description: Only answer 'Yes' if this is the sole purpose for the works.
data.howMeasured:
In this context, the definition of disabled comes from 2 pieces of legislation:

  • Section 6 of the Equalities Act 2010 defines a disabled person over 18 years old
  • Part 3 of the Children Act 1989 defines a disabled child

data.info:
The planning history of your property is made up of past planning applications.

Those planning applications may contain planning conditions which can remove permitted development rights. This means you will need planning permission for certain projects.

It is important that you check the planning history of your property to find out if you need planning permission.
data.content:
Have you checked if there are any planning conditions that might affect your project?

Some properties have a planning condition on them that limits what you can do without planning permission.

We will check this as part of your application but you can check this yourself before applying using our planning records.

Check planning conditions. (opens in a new tab)
data.howMeasured:
A historic planning condition is a specific condition attached to a previous planning decision after 1947.

For example, planning permission may have been granted for a new home, on the condition that no additional windows are added in the future under permitted development.

Planning conditions can be found within the text of the original decision letter.

Contact our planning team if you are unsure about the impact of a planning condition on your property.

data.info:
You must include a site outline that shows the area of land you are applying about.

This is a legal requirement for all planning applications.
data.title: Draw an outline of the site.
data.policyRef: The Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) Order 2015, Part 8, Class A
data.description: Your site outline should include all the changes. In most cases the site outline will encompass the entire property. Drawing this outline will allow you to check what planning constraints apply to this property.
data.howMeasured:
Ways to provide a site outline

You can either draw the site outline on this website or upload a location plan drawing. You do not need to do both.

Drawing the site outline on this website helps us accurately identify things that might affect your project. For example, if your site is in a conservation area.

If you choose to draw the site outline and upload a location plan drawing, make sure the red site outlines are the same on all drawings. This will avoid delays to your application.

What to include 

For houses, flats and small premises, the site outline is often the same as the property boundary. This includes any gardens or outside spaces.

The site outline should cover:

  • all the changes up to a public road or pavement
  • any work outside the property boundary (such as a dropped kerb)
  • areas that will be closed off during the work
  • access areas to the works (such as an alleyway)
data.descriptionForUploading:
Your location must:

- Be based on an accurate, recognisable map

- Be drawn to a scale, labelled, and/or marked with a scale bar

- The site outline must be shown in red.

- There must be a North point shown somewhere on the map

data.info: Pubs in the Borough of Southwark are affected by Article 4 directions that remove Part 3, Class L of the General Permitted Development Order (**Class L – dwellinghouses to small HMOs**). This means that any change of use from a self contained dwelling house (use Class C3) **TO** a small (between 3 - 6 people) house in multiple occupation (HMO) (Use Class C4) use will require planning permission.

data.howMeasured:
Select only as many as you need to describe the project once.

For example, if you are adding an extension you do not need to include any windows or doors that are part of that extension. However, if you are both adding an extension and adding new windows elsewhere to an existing part of the building, you need to select both.

The term 'changes' includes both physical works and changes in the use of the property, if appropriate.

data.info:
From 1 August 2021 conversions of properties under class E to residential under Class MA need planning permission. This means changes of use from Commercial, Business and Leisure (Class E) to residential (Class C3) will need planning permission in the following areas:

Central Activities Zone

Railway Arches

Town centres

New Southwark Plan Site Allocations

Strategic Protected Industrial Land

Shopping frontages
